facts.text: Since 1932, first appellant sole proprietor of member firm Messrs. Narrondass Manordass, member of East India Cotton Association Ltd.; second appellant partnership firm carrying on business as cotton merchants and commission agents.
Respondents partnership firm and member of Association.
Between September 23, 1947, and December 10, 1947, member firm sold to respondents 2,300 bales of Broach Vijay Fine 3/4 Navsari and/or Bardoli 7/8 Cotton for March-April 1948 delivery.
Out of 2,300 bales, 1,100 disposed by Havalas; remaining 1,200 had cross-contracts; 700 bales outstanding, member firm liable to deliver to respondents.
Member firm failed to deliver 700 bales; respondents invoiced back on May 3, 1948; Rs. 1,07,530-8-0 due thereon; total for 2,300 bales Rs. 1,79,749-8-0 due.
Respondents sent eight debit notes and consolidated debit note for Rs. 1,79,749-8-0.
Contract notes signed by Ramanlal Nagindas, salesman in partnership firm; appellants contended no authority and contracts not per by-laws.
Partnership firm paid Rs. 1,79,749-8-0 on May 7, 1948, and Rs. 350 penalty on June 6, 1948, without prejudice to rights/contentions.
Ramanlal entered similar transactions with others; member firm filed petitions A/51, A/52, A/55, A/56 of 1949 under s.33 Arbitration Act for no arbitration agreement.
Justice Shah held contracts void on August 20, 1950, as not per by-laws; petitions allowed.
Respondents' Art.136 petitions dismissed by Supreme Court circa April 6, 1951.
Appellants demanded return of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 with 6% interest by letter May 2, 1951.
Suit No. 468 of 1951 filed May 7, 1951, for recovery with interest/costs.
Plaint averred contracts void under Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932: no difference above/below settlement rate (bylaws 139,141); no measurement provision (bylaw 80).
Appellants amended plaint: implied agreement to repay if not bound.
Trial Judge (single Judge Bombay HC) followed Justice Shah: measurement omission immaterial; settlement difference omission voids contracts; no implied agreement; suit dismissed.
Appellate Bench Bombay HC confirmed dismissal on different grounds: measurement ok; no obligation for settlement difference; implied agreement exists but contracts valid.
Delivery contracts not put through periodical settlements; term obsolete.

legal_issues.text: Whether the contracts were not in accordance with the by-laws of the Association and therefore void under s.8 Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, due to omissions of measurement term and difference above/below settlement rate in contract notes.

petitioner_arguments.text: Contract notes omitted difference above/below settlement rate of hedge contracts (bylaws 139,141) and measurement (bylaw 80), rendering void; strict compliance required; even if no agreement on difference, must state 'nil'.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bylaw 80; Bombay Cotton Contracts Act s.8; precedents like Burchell v. Thompson

petitioner_arguments.text: Suspension of bylaw 101 made measurement specification essential as part of goods description.
Payments made without prejudice imply agreement to repay if contracts void.

respondent_arguments.text: No by-law requires stating difference above/below; if no agreement, bylaw 141 applies settlement on hedge rate basis; no obligation to fill term.
Bylaw 101 suspended since 1942; no need for measurement; provisions obsolete as no hedge contracts with different numbers, no periodical settlements for delivery contracts.

court_reasoning.text: Substantial compliance with form sufficient, not literal; per Radhakisson; omissions not material.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Form not stereotyped; must contain all terms but substantial compliance enough.

court_reasoning.text: Measurement term basis disappeared with bylaw 101 suspension 1942; bales bound with ropes, allowances in bylaws 96/119; no need to mention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Omission does not alter legal effect; trade practice accounted for extras.

court_reasoning.text: No obligation to agree/fill difference; if no agreement, settlement on hedge rate; no need to state 'nil'; hedge contract changed to I.C.C., form outdated; delivery contracts not settled periodically, term obsolete.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Practice suspended bylaws 139/141 operation; superfluous to fill blanks.

holdings.text: Contracts in accordance with by-laws; substantial compliance; not void under s.8 Bombay Cotton Contracts Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Substantial compliance with form sufficient; literal not essential.
Departure from characteristic part of form voids contract.

precedents_cited.case_name: Parsons v. Brand Cols v. Dickson

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932
statutes_cited.relevance: Contracts not in accordance with by-laws of recognized association void.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitions filed for declaration of no arbitration agreement.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding contracts valid and in accordance with by-laws; appellants not entitled to recover Rs. 1,80,099-8-0; confirmed High Court decree.

key_quotes.text: "The only question for our determination in this appeal is whether the contracts between the parties were not in accordance with the by-laws of the Association and therefore void."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Their Lordships of the Privy Council there held that the form prescribed was not a stereotyped one and that literal compliance with it was not essential."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key principle of substantial compliance applied.

key_quotes.text: "We cannot part with this appeal without observing that the whole difficulty has been created by reason of the Association not having made the necessary alterations in the contract form."
key_quotes.speaker: court
